posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Emma Orczy

Baroness Emma Magdolna Rozália Mária Jozefa Borbála Orczy de Orci (1865-1947) was a Hungarian-born British writer known for inventing the ‘hero with a secret identity’ trope.

Born in Tarnaörs, Hungary and raised across Europe during a period of unpopularity for nobility, Orczy started writing for money. Her first stories were unsuccessful, but in 1903 she wrote The Scarlet Pimpernel. A massive success, especially as a play on London’s West End, it introduced a number of tropes now standard in superhero media.

It used a hero with a secret identity with a signature weapon, the ability to outthink opponents, a calling card (the eponymous scarlet pimpernel, a small flower), and an in-universe following. Her protagonist, Sir Percy Blakeney, hides behind a public face as a somewhat stupid playboy–similar to Bruce Wayne.

Orczy wrote over a dozen sequels, as well as rather popular mystery novels. Lady Molly of Scotland Yard is an early example of a female detective. All told, Orcazy wrote over 50 novels and a number of short stories and plays.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Mama Cax

An American-Haitian disabled rights activist and fashion model, Cacsmy Brutus (1989-2019) a famous face of often marginally groups in the high-glamour world of fashion.

Born in Brooklyn and raised in Haiti, Cax was diagnosed with osteosarcoma and lung cancer. Treatments lasted for years and often didn’t work, and at 16 her right leg had to be amputated.

Though at first she hid her prosthetic leg, she did not let it slow her down. Cax received a bachelor’s and a master’s in International Studies and was working in the office of the Mayor of New York City when she started modeling.

Cax walked the runway for Chromat and Rihanna’s Fenty Beauty and appeared on ad campaigns for Tommy Hilfiger and Sephora. In 2018, she walked at New York Fashion Week and appeared on the cover of Teen Vogue. She was the face of Olay sunscreen and participated in the New York Marathon in a wheelchair.

All of these amazing accomplishments were things she did while still sick, and in December 2019, at the age of 30, she died from blood clots in her lung.

Mama Cax was a trailblazing Black woman determined not to let any circumstances keep her from her place in the spotlight or miss out on any experiences.

Image Description: three color photographs of model Mama Cax, a Black woman with no hair. In the first, she is wearing a black and yellow athleisure outfit. She is standing on a runway with a prosthetic leg and canes. In the second, she is wearing sunglasses and a bikini and is standing against a blue wall with no prosthetics. In the third, she is sitting in a handcycle at the NYC marathon, wearing a blue tracksuit and helmet, raising a peace sign in the air.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Native American Sign Languages

Native American groups had multiple regional sign-languages used for communication. Like spoken languages, sign languages have their own grammatical structure and vocabulary.

Hawai'i Sign Language (HSL) is the sign language of the Hawaiian Islands. While there are no attestations to its existance pre-American contact, HSL is considered an indigenous language is an primarily used be elderly people. It was recognized in the 1820s and is a language isolate–it shares no similarities to suggest it is part of American Sign Language (ASL). Not formally recognized until 2013, HSL has only about 30 native speakers and is considered ‘virtually extinct’. HSL is believed to be the last undiscovered language in the United States.

Inuit Sign Language (IUR) (Atgangmuurngniq or Uukturausingit) is the indigenous sign language of Inuit communities in the Canadian Arctic, most notably Nunavut. IUR works as both a trade language and as the primary language for Deaf Inuit. Certain communities with high levels of hereditary deafness use IUR frequently, and it functions as a primary language of the community.

Plateau Sign Language was a contact pidgin used across the Columbian Plateau (in what is now the US states of Washington, Oregon, and Idaho). As a contact language, it was used for trade and to communicate between groups with different languages. Plateau Sign Language went extint in the 18th century, and was replaced by…

Plains Sign Talk (PISL–Plains Indian Sign Language), at one point the lingua franca over central Canada, the United States, and northern Mexico, a region of over 1 million square miles (2.6 million square kilometers). PISL is a trade language and a contact language, and was also the daily usage language for Deaf people. One of the best studied indigenous sign languages, PISL was certainly fully formed before European arrival in the Americas.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Captain Robert Smalls

A former slave turned politician and ship captain, Robert Smalls (1839-1915) was one of the heroes of the American Civil War.

His mother was a house slave and his father was an unknown white man. Smalls worked in the fields until the age of 12, when he was hired out to work in the dockyards of Charleston, South Carolina.

After the start of the Civil War in 1861, Smalls had proven his worth around boats enough to be a wheelman (essentially a helmsman, but without the prestige of the title reserve for White people). Smalls was assigned to work on the CSS Planter, a military transport ship with the job of laying mines and delivering supplies around the Confederate waterways.

In May 1862, Smalls had permission for the families of the slaves to visit the ship while the White officers disembarked, leaving the slaves on board overnight. At 3am, Smalls put on a captain’s uniform and guided the ship across Confederate waters and up to the Union Navy fleet and put up a white bed sheet as a flag. at Fort Sumter, Smalls and the Planter made contact with the USS Onward, where he surrendered the ship and its cargo, making all onboard free men.

Just 23 years old, Smalls became known as a wartime hero across the North and a hated man in the South. Smalls worked for the Union Navy, and then the Army, where he was known as one of the best and brightest men of any race. Smalls was present at 17 major battles and engagements, particularly useful in helping ships avoid the mines that he had previously laid.

After the war, Smalls returned to South Carolina, where he purchased his former master’s house, started a school for former slaves, and was elected to the United States House of Representatives.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Charles Frederick Worth

The Father of Fashion, the Head of the House of Worth.

Charles Frederick Worth (1825-1895) was an English fashion designer, generally considered to be the first fashion designer (by modern definitions) in the world.

Worth was born to a poor family in a small market town in England. His father abandoned his mother, Worth, and his four siblings (only one other of which survived til adulthood)–after draining all their money. Worth began working at age 11 in a printer’s shop, but after only a year he moved to London to begin his apprenticeship in a department store. Before he even turned 20, he was working at a leading British textile store.

[a fancy dress constume]

At the age of 21, Worth moved to Paris. Though he spoke absolutely no French at the time, he quickly became a sales assistant at a fabric firm that sold expensive silks and cashmeres to high society, including the dressmakers at the Parisian court.

[an evening dress]

Worth began sewing dresses–first simple, but eventually gained enough success and popular to open a dress department. His dresses became famous for their beauty and craftsmanship, and were displayed in The Great Exhibition of 1851 in London and the Exposition Universelle of 1855 in Paris.

[a peacock dress]

He quickly found success making ball dresses for the princesses of Europe, but in 1860, he became the favored dressmaker for Empress Eugénie of the French Empire. She ordered 250 dresses from Worth for the opening of the Suez Canal in Egypt.

[an evening dress]

His dresses became widely known and recognizable–one could tell a Worth dress just by looking at it. He also changed the social dynamics–rather than dressmakers doing in-home fittings, his salon became a social hub of the wealthy and well-connected. Worth also, famously, outright told his clients (noblewomen, mainly) if he thought their fashion choices were ugly.

[an evening dress]

His fashion house has over 1,200 staff at its peak sewing dresses, mixing hand sewing and machine sewing for custom orders and showcases. He had two major innovations: he narrowed the silhouette of the crinoline–then large enough to be a physical hindrance to women–and he invented a walking skirt with a hemline at ankle length. The scandal!

[a walking dress]

He died at age 69 in Paris of pneumonia. More than just a dressmaker, he completely changed the marketing and selling of dresses in the fashion industry. He, unique for his time, viewed fashion as an art foremost, creating dresses that were uniquely his. He was the first designer to put labels in his clothes.

[an evening dress]

posts.body:
Dee Farmer

The American Civil Liberties Union calls her legal fight, Farmer v Brennan (1994), one of the most important victories you’ve never heard of.

Dee Farmer was a Black trans woman who was convicted of credit card fraud in 1986 and incarcerated in federal prison for men. Farmer was violently and sexually assaulted. She sued prison officials for her mistreatment despite not having a lawyer and knowing she would face retaliation.

It would take five years for the Supreme Court to hear her case, but they ruled unanimously (9-0) in her favor, saying that “deliberate indifference” to a substantial of harm to an inmate can make a prison official liable under the Eighth Amendment, and knowing that Farmer was a trans woman in a men’s prison (and thus more likely to be assaulted), the prison officials failed. This allowed Farmer to move forward with suing to prison.

Excessive bail shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual punishments inflicted.

The Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

This case has been used in tens of thousands of court decisions since and was directly referenced in the Prison Rape Elimination Act and the Department of Justice’s regulations for implementing it. These regulations include key protections for trans people and making it easier for trans inmates to go to the correct prison.

Farmer v Brennan was the first time the Supreme Court direct addressed sexual assault in prisons, and essentially every important federal action to curb it is thanks to Farmer’s brave actions.

Did You Know?

Upon learning that Louisiana Governor William C. C. Claiborne put a bounty of $500 on the head of famous pirate Jean Lafitte, Lafitte put a bounty of $5000 on the head of Governor Claiborne. Neither bounty was ever collected.

posts.summary: Edelweiss Pirates and the Leipzig Meuten
posts.body:
Edelweiss Pirates and the Leipzig Meuten

Two examples of youth resistance groups in Nazi Germany, the Edelweiss Pirates and the Leipzig Meuten, were examples of effective resistance against Nazi activity.

The Edelweiss Pirates were loosely organized, mostly made up of students who dropped out of school as a way to avoid being forced into Hitler Youth or military conscription. They were used violent action against Hitler Youth and valued anti-authoritarian actions–many of their complaints started when Nazis began heavily controlling leisure time and spaces. The Edelweiss Pirates helped distribute Allied propaganda and move Army deserts. One of their slogans was “Eternal War on the Hitler Youth”.

The Leipzig Meuten were similar. Based in Leipzig, they were gangs of children, teenagers, and young adults. Their goals were more political in nature and members were from working-class families. The group was largely Communist in its roots, so they were persecuted more ruthlessly than the Edelweiss Pirates

posts.body:
Jan Opletal

Though he was just a student, Jan Opletal (1915-1939) became a figure of the Czech resistance against Nazi encroachment.

The eighth child of a family from a small village, his parents lied about his age to send him to school earlier. An intelligent and disciplined child, he excelled in school and began to study medicine at the Charles University in Prague.

In his third year studying medicine, in 1939, Hitler and the Nazis invaded Prague. That year, a hundred thousand people, including Opletal, protested against the Nazi regime. The Nazi police opened fire on the crowd, killing a baker and wounding Opletal in the stomach. He was rushed to the hospital and died two weeks later.

More than 3,000 students attended his memorial, which turned into an anti-Nazi protest. In response, authorities raided student dorms and eventually closed all Czech universities and colleges. Nine student union leaders were executed.

November 17th is International Students’ Day in memory of Jan Opletal.

posts.body:
Skaay

An important storyteller of the Haida, Skaay (born c. 1827) was an important figure in protecting the stories of Haida mythology.

The Haida are one of the indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast of North America (now Canada and Alaska). Skaay (in church records, his name is written as “Robert McKay”, “Sky”, and “John Sky”) was born at Qquuna and lived in the village of Ttanuu. Skaay was blind and physical disabled, and he was completely illiterate. He kept stories in their original oral tradition, but in 1900 allowed John Swanton and Henry Moody to write them down.

In particular, Skaay dictated the Qqunna Cycle, the longest known Haida epic poem, the Qquuna Qiighawaay, the history of Skaay’s family, and Raven Travelling (many indigenous American religions, including Haida, had a trickster Raven as a central figure).

posts.body:
Konrad Adenauer

The first chancellor of West Germany, Konrad Hermann Joseph Adenauer (1876-1967) who is largely responsible for Germany’s current status as a prosperous and well-respected nation after World War II.

A successful politician during World War I and the Interbellum period, he only lost his job in 1933 when the Nazis would not work with him (his previous strategy had been to attempt to compromise with and then largely ignore the Nazis as mayor of Cologne–this resulted in his dismissal and the freezing of all his bank accounts). Adenauer was imprisoned for two days after the Night of Long Knives (a series of extrajudicial executions in summer 1934) and spent two years changing residences and living with friends for fear of reprisals. He was imprisoned again in 1944 and nearly deported.

After the end of World War II, the American occupation forces reinstalled him as Mayor of Cologne, but he was dismissed by the British. After this, but without living in fear, Adenauer began building a new political party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), his influence led him to be chosen to help draft the new German constitution, the “Basic Law” in 1949, and became the first head of government.

As Chancellor of West Germany, Adenauer focused on integrating with the West (most notably joining NATO), but empowering the German economy and industry. Controversially, Adenauer opposed denazification (but preferred reparations for victims of Nazis).

Germany today is a powerful, peaceful, and respected world leader. Much of this is due to the cunning and dedicated work of Konrad Adenauer.

posts.body:
Queen Velu Nachiyar

Rani Velu Nachiyar (1730-1796) was a Sivaganga queen and the first Indian queen to wage war against the East India Company.

Nachiyar was the only child of the King and Queen of the Ramnad kingdom (now in the Tamil Nadu state, southeast Indian coast) and was raised to be its princess. She was trained in combat, including armed combat, archery, and horse riding. She was at least trilingual and could study in more languages.

When her husband was killed by soldiers of the East India Company, she escaped the battlefield with her daughter. She formed an army, made alliances, and launched a campaign against the East India Company. Nachiyar successfully arranged an attack to blow up their ammunition, and was able to rule for 10 more years. Her daughters, Vellachi Nachiyar, rule after her.

posts.body:
Agent Garbo

Agent Garbo (to the British) | Agent Alaric (to the Germans) was a freelance double agent in World War II. Real name Juan Pujol García (1912-1998), Pujol was a devout anti-extremist after his experiences in the Spanish Civil War.

He decided to spy for Britain and contacted the British Embassy in Madrid about this. Since this is not the way anything works, he was rejected.

Instead of being normal about this, Pujol simply began to spy for the United Kingdom by himself. He created a false identity as a Nazi supporter and became a German spy. He moved to Lisbon, told the Germans he was in Britain, and made an entirely fake ‘network’ of spies to create entirely fake reports.

Eventually, he was so successful that Pujol was taken on by MI5, his original goal. With his handler, Pujol got the Germans funding a network of 27 (imaginary) agents and played a key role in Operation Fortitude, the false operation that covered up the invasion of Normandy.

By the end of the war, Pujol received the 2nd Class Iron Cross signifying services to Nazi Germany and, four months later, became a Member of the Order of the British Empire.

I freely admit this post is a present to myself, Agent Garbo is one of my favorite figures in all of history. Books about Agent Garbo include

Agent Garbo: The Brilliant, Eccentric Secret Agent Who Tricked Hitler and Saved D-Day by Stephan Talty

Operation Garbo: The Personal Story of the Most Successful Spy of World War II (Dialogue Espionage Classics) By Nigel West and Juan Pujol García

The Counterfeit Spy by Sefton Delmer

posts.body:
Henry Viscardi Jr.

An American disability rights activist, Henry Viscardi Jr. (1912-2004) was a leader and well-known pioneer in education.

Born in New York City with “arrested development of the lower limbs”, or a congenital deformity of his legs, Viscardi spent the first six years of his life in hospitals. Afterward, though, he breezed through school and helped care for his family after the death of his father.

As an adult, he stood 3 feet 8 inches tall. He went to Fordham University, learned to sailboats and dance, and at the age of 27 received his first artificial legs.

During World War II, Viscardi worked with amputees as an officer for the Red Cross and noticed that veterans with physical disabilities were unable to find unemployment. This started the mission he would continue his entire life.

In 1952, Viscardi founded Abilities, Inc. (now The Viscardi Center), a network of non-profit organizations that help educate and employ people with disabilities. He focused on empowering others and giving them the tools to be successful.

His efforts helped inspire the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) of 1975 and the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990.

The Viscardi Center now offers the Henry Viscardi Achievement Award to recognize leaders with disabilities around the world.

Henry Viscardi Jr.

An American disability rights activist, Henry Viscardi Jr. (1912-2004) was a leader and well-known pioneer in education.

Born in New York City with “arrested development of the lower limbs”, or a congenital deformity of his legs, Viscardi spent the first six years of his life in hospitals. Afterward, though, he breezed through school and helped care for his family after the death of his father.

As an adult, he stood 3 feet 8 inches tall. He went to Fordham University, learned to sailboats and dance, and at the age of 27 received his first artificial legs.

During World War II, Viscardi worked with amputees as an officer for the Red Cross and noticed that veterans with physical disabilities were unable to find unemployment. This started the mission he would continue his entire life.

In 1952, Viscardi founded Abilities, Inc. (now The Viscardi Center), a network of non-profit organizations that help educate and employ people with disabilities. He focused on empowering others and giving them the tools to be successful.

His efforts helped inspire the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) of 1975 and the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990.

The Viscardi Center now offers the Henry Viscardi Achievement Award to recognize leaders with disabilities around the world.

Did You Know?

17th- and 18th-century European nobility played a bloodsport known as fox tossing, where they would toss foxes into the air. It was played by both men and women.

posts.body:
Mary Ann Bugg

One of only a couple notable female bushrangers, Mary Ann Bugg (1834-1905) was an Aboriginal woman of the Worimi people.

Born to a Worimi mother and a convict father from Essex, England, Mary Ann was sent to Sydney to be educated.

Bugg worked with her lover, Frederick Ward (“Captain Thunderbolt”), whom she helped escape Cockatoo Island. Bushrangers were those who lived in the bush and made a living by robbery, similar to British highwaymen or American Wild West outlaws. Bushranging lasted for over a century, having significant influence and popularity today. Native-born bushrangers were among some of the first Australian nationalists and folk heroes.

Bugg was often described as a ‘young man’ as she wore trousers and rode astride. She was in charge of intelligence gathering, keeping camp, and helping organize robberies. She was apprehended by the police three times, though at least two were overturned.

posts.body:
Jane Addams

An author, activist, and social worker, Jane Addams (1860-1935) was the first American woman to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize (in 1931) and is considered the founder of American social work.

Addams was a leader in women’s suffrage, arguing that the role of government mirrored to the role of women in the household, and thus women were better equipped than men for some things, and thus needed to have a public voice. Addams also was a co-founder of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and was considered the first woman “public philosopher” in the United States.

Most importantly, Jane Addams founded the Hull House in Chicago, one of the most important settlement houses in history. The settlement movement sought to bring together rich and poor people and to provide social services for those without. Addams got the idea from Toynbee Hall, a London settlement house, but rather than a Christian-based charity like in England, Addams focused on democratic ideals.
